questions.text: Which of the following effects of adrenaline would be blocked by phentolamine (alpha receptor blocker) but NOT by propranolol (beta receptor antagonist)?

options.label: A
options.text: Release of renin from JG cells

options.label: C
options.text: Tremors due to stimulation of muscle spindle

options.label: D
options.text: Contraction of the vascular smooth muscle

questions.correct_answer: D. Contraction of the vascular smooth muscle

questions.text: Atropine is useful in organophosphate poisoning because it:

options.label: C
options.text: Binds with both nicotinic and muscarinic acetylcholine receptors

options.label: D
options.text: Is a competitive antagonist of acetylcholine

questions.correct_answer: D. Is a competitive antagonist of acetylcholine
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Is a competitive antagonist of acetylcholine

questions.text: During your rural posting after the internship, you encounter a patient of acute cardiac failure. Your preferred drug for this condition is dobutamine. However, it is not available there. Which of the following other drugs, or combination of drugs, would be a suitable alternative, giving the pharmacologic equivalent of what you want the dobutamine to do?
questions.correct_answer: A. Norepinephrine plus phentolamine

questions.text: An old patient Ravi, having asthma and glaucoma is to receive a β blocker. Regarding β blocking drugs:

options.label: B
options.text: Esmolol’s pharmacokinetics are compatible with chronic topical use

options.label: D
options.text: Timolol lacks the local anaesthetic effects of propranolol

questions.correct_answer: D. Timolol lacks the local anaesthetic effects of propranolol
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Timolol lacks the local anesthetic effects of propranolol

questions.text: Jugal, a patient suffering from hypertension, was administered propranolol. While it successfully managed the hypertension, it unfortunately dropped his resting heart rate to 50 beats per minute. Which of the following β blockers can be used as a suitable replacement for propranolol in Jugal's case that wouldn't result in severe bradycardia?
questions.correct_answer: A. Pindolol

questions.text: A patient receives bethanechol after abdominal surgery. Her heart rate falls slightly and she experiences some wheezing. Which of the following best explains these cardiac and pulmonary responses?

options.label: C
options.text: Patient has undiagnosed interstitial lung disease

questions.correct_answer: A. Expected side effects of bethanechol
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Expected side effects of bethanechol

questions.text: After undergoing a comprehensive eye exam, a patient exits the ophthalmologist's office and steps into bright sunlight. The topical drug administered during the exam not only dilated the patient's pupils but also affected their ability to focus on nearby objects. Which of the following drugs is most similar in its effects to the one given to the patient?
questions.correct_answer: B. Homatropine

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman with diagnosed myasthenia gravis presents with profound skeletal muscle weakness. We are unsure whether she is experiencing a cholinergic crisis or a myasthenic crisis, so we administer a usually appropriate dose of parenteral edrophonium. Assume the patient was actually experiencing a cholinergic crisis. Which of the following is the most likely response to the drug?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypertensive crisis from peripheral vascular constriction

options.label: B
options.text: Myocardial ischemia, and angina, from drug-induced tachycardia and coronary vasoconstriction

options.label: C
options.text: Prompt improvement of skeletal muscle tone and function

options.label: D
options.text: Ventilatory distress or failure due to paralysis of respiratory muscles

questions.correct_answer: D. Ventilatory distress or failure due to paralysis of respiratory muscles

questions.text: Neeraj, a farmer comes to you in the emergency in comatose state. Patient had profuse sweating and lacrimation. Diarrhea and urination were apparent. On examination pupil was constricted and BP of the farmer was 80/60 mm Hg. You make a diagnosis of anticholinesterase poisoning. You decide to administer him atropine. All of the following actions will be reversed by atropine EXCEPT:
questions.correct_answer: C. Muscle paralysis

questions.text: A patient has supraventricular tachycardia. We inject a drug and heart rate falls to a normal or at least more acceptable level. Although this drug caused the desired response, it did so without any direct effect on the heart. Which of the following drugs was most likely used?
questions.correct_answer: B. Phenylephrine

questions.text: A substance abuser self-administers cocaine and experiences a variety of significant changes in cardiovascular function, in addition to the CNS-stimulating effects for which the drug is used. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism by which the cocaine causes its main peripheral effects?

options.label: A
options.text: Activation of α-2-adrenergic receptors leading to increased NA release

options.label: B
options.text: Blockage of NA reuptake via the amine pump

options.label: C
options.text: Direct activation of postsynaptic α-and –β adrenergic receptors

questions.correct_answer: B. Blockage of NA reuptake via the amine pump
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Blockage of NA reuptake via the amine pump

questions.text: We administer an “effective” dose of a drug Y and observe the following responses: Stimulates the heart Dilates some blood vessels but constricts none Dilates the bronchi Raises blood glucose levels in presence of hypoglycemia No effect on the size of the pupil Drug Y acts on which of the following receptors?

options.label: B
options.text: Agonist of all α and β-adrenergic receptors

options.label: C
options.text: Agonist of α1 and α2 receptors

options.label: D
options.text: Agonist of β1 and β2 receptors

questions.correct_answer: D. Agonist of β1 and β2 receptors
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Agonist of β1 and β2 receptors

questions.text: Which of the following can be blocked by atropine?

options.label: A
options.text: Bradycardia caused by infusion of acetylcholine

options.label: B
options.text: Increased blood pressure caused by nicotine

options.label: C
options.text: Increased skeletal muscle strength caused by neostigmine

questions.correct_answer: A. Bradycardia caused by infusion of acetylcholine
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Bradycardia caused by infusion of acetylcholine

questions.text: A new drug has been found to act by inhibiting VMAT-2. Which of the following statement regarding this drug is likely to be TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Blocks both α and β receptor mediated effects of injected adrenaline

options.label: B
options.text: Does not block any effect of injected nor-adrenaline

options.label: C
options.text: Does not block the effects of sympathetic nerve Stimulation

questions.correct_answer: B. Does not block any effect of injected nor-adrenaline
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Does not block any effect of injected nor-adrenaline

questions.text: A healthy adult subject is given an intravenous injection of a test drug. Both blood pressure and total peripheral resistance rise promptly. This is associated with a reduction of heart rate. In repeated experiments we find that the vasopressor response is not affected by pretreatment with prazosin (alpha blocker). However, pretreatment with atropine prevents the bardycardia. The test drug was most likely which of the following?
questions.correct_answer: B. Angiotensin II

questions.text: Cholinomimetic drugs can be used for the treatment of all the following conditions except:
questions.correct_answer: B. Bradycardia

questions.text: A patient presents in the emergency department in great distress and with the following signs and symptoms: Mental confusion Clear lungs, no wheezing or crepitations High heart rate Absence of bowel sounds Distended abdomen Full bladder Hot, dry skin Absence of lacrimal, salivary secretions Very high fever Dilated pupils that do not respond to light Which of the following drug overdose is most likely to be responsible for these signs and symptoms?
questions.correct_answer: C. Atropine

questions.text: All of the following are features of atenolol in comparison to propranolol EXCEPT?

options.label: A
options.text: It is ineffective in suppressing muscle tremor

options.label: C
options.text: It is less likely to cause bradycardia

options.label: D
options.text: It is less likely to worsen Raynaud’s disease

questions.correct_answer: C. It is less likely to cause bradycardia
questions.explanation: Ans.C. It is less likely to cause bradycardia

questions.text: In general, structures that are affected by sympathetic activation respond to both sympathetic neural activation and to the hormonal component, adrenaline released from the adrenal medulla. Which of the following structures is unique in that it responds to adrenaline, but not nor-adrenaline?
questions.correct_answer: C. Bronchus

questions.text: A 28 yr old woman has been treated with several autonomic drugs for about a month. Which of the following signs would distinguish between an overdose of a muscarinic blocker and a ganglionic blocker?
questions.correct_answer: B. Postural hypotension
